Intelligent Communication Systems and Networking Lab (ICSNLab) welcome graduate students, researchers and collaborators from China and worldwide to join us in our interdisciplinary research involving machine learning, optical communications and networking, and digital signal processing to make important advances and develop new technologies for future autonomous and intelligent communication networks and sensing systems.
Machine learning (ML) has revolutionized a number of science and engineering disciplines over the past few years. It is also being hailed as a new direction of innovation to transform future fiber-optic communication systems and solve several critical problems in optical networks that cannot be easily tackled using conventional approaches. Over the past few years, serious efforts have been made by both industry and academia to exploit ML methods in various aspects of fiber-optic communications and networking. Examples of such works include ML-based: end-to-end learning of complete fiber-optic communication system, adaptive allocation of network resources, proactive fault detection/prevention and root cause analysis, prediction of lightpaths‚Äô quality, optical performance monitoring, cross-layer optimizations for software-defined networks (SDNs), intrusions detection and network security management, etc.
We are a group of enthusiastic researchers at Tsinghua-Berkeley Shenzhen Institute (TBSI), Tsinghua University, working on the fusion of ML algorithms and next-generation fiber-optic communication networks as well as sensing systems. We bring together ML concepts, communication theory, physics of light-matter interaction, and the engineering spirit of making real-world impacts. We aim to develop new and interesting ideas and demonstrate their practical applications. We welcome students from China and all around the world to work together in making important technological advancements towards realizing ML-based solutions for future intelligent optical network infrastructures and smart sensing systems.

summary: We review application of machine learning methods to tackle fiber linear/nonlinear impairments as well as to estimate crucial signal parameters in optical networks. Recent works involving hierarchical learning approaches are also discussed.
title: Machine learning methods for optical communication systems and networks

summary: Machine learning (ML) has disrupted a wide range of science and engineering disciplines in recent years. ML applications in optical communications and networking are also gaining more attention, particularly in the areas of nonlinear transmission systems, optical performance monitoring, and cross-layer network optimizations for software-defined networks. However, the extent to which ML techniques can benefit optical communications and networking is not clear and this is partly due to an insufficient understanding of the nature of ML concepts. This paper aims to describe the mathematical foundations of basic ML techniques from communication theory and signal processing perspectives, which in turn will shed light on the types of problems in optical communications and networking that naturally warrant ML use. This will be followed by an overview of ongoing ML research in optical communications and networking with a focus on physical layer issues.
title: An optical communication‚Äôs perspective on machine learning and its applications

summary: This is an invited talk presented at workshop ‚ÄúHow machine learning can revolutionize optical fiber communications?‚Äù We discussed the development, advantages as well as disadvantages of analytical models and machine learning models in the area of QoT estimation.
title: Comparison of ML and analytical models for lightpaths QoT estimation

summary: A novel ultra-long distributed vibration sensor using forward transmission, coherent detection, and a frequency-shifted optical delay line is proposed and experimentally demonstrated. In the proposed scheme, a pair of multi-span optical fibers are deployed for sensing. A frequency-shifted optical delay line consisting of an acousto-optic modulator and a time delay fiber is used at the far end of these two fibers. Coherent detection is used to retrieve the vibration-induced phase fluctuations of the base-band signals as well as the intermediate frequency signals generated by the frequency-shifted optical delay line. Two differential phase signals can be calculated from the obtained phase fluctuations, which can then be used to localize the vibration events by correlation operations. Localization of a few hundred Hz, around 1 kHz and tens of kHz vibrations has been experimentally demonstrated over a total length of 1230 km sensing fiber. Less than 125 m spatial resolution can be obtained over the 615 km sensing range for vibrations with larger than 1 kHz frequency by using averaging of 30 times tests due to the nature of asynchronous operation. Frequencies from infrasound to ultrasound can be detected. The proposed scheme has advantages of ultrabroad frequency response, ultra-long sensing range and simple sensing structure due to the nature of forward transmission and coherent detection. The sensing length can be further extended using more fiber spans and erbium-doped fiber amplifiers, making it a promising candidate for vibration event detection and localization in long-haul and ultra-long-haul fiber links.
title: Forward transmission based ultra-long distributed vibration sensing with wide frequency response

summary: Optical performance monitoring (OPM) is the estimation and acquisition of different physical parameters of transmitted signals and various components of an optical network. OPM functionalities are indispensable in ensuring robust network operation and plays a key role in enabling flexibility and improve overall network efficiency. We review the development of various OPM techniques for direct-detection systems and digital coherent systems and discuss future OPM challenges in flexible and elastic optical networks.
title: Optical performance monitoring: a review of current and future technologies

Digital twins has earned its reputation in manufactures, optical networks could also benefit from its digital twin, which is built upon the historical record, physical model and real-time monitoring data of the optical network in real world. The most important application of digital twins is to perform experiments on this digital replica rather than the real system, which helps reduce the risk and provides opptunity for bolder attempt.
We are establishing framework for digital twins of optical system, novel architectures and efficient algorithms are being expected.
summary: We are establishing the framework of introducing digital twins into optical communication systems.
title: Digital twins of optical networks

content: When deploying network control or prediction algorithms, it is often faced with mild or drastic environmental changes. One kind of uncertainty comes from the change of the external environment itself over time, and the other comes from the topology change of the network itself. We work on developing a domain adaption paradigm that minimizes the impact of environmental changes on algorithm performance.
summary: We developed robust models for deploying to cross-domains in the real-world transmission system.
title: Domain adaption in optical transmission system

content: Analogizing the topological phase of matter with substitutes in optics, topological photonics can make the transmission of light highly robust, which can be immune to some defects in the manufacturing process of integrated photonic devices. Two dimensional photonic crystal is the most common platform to realize topological photonic effect. Through some geometric design of topological PhC, some common photonic devices can be realized, which can be applied to communication, sensing, etc.
summary: We are aimming to use topological photonic crystal to develop robust integrated photonic device.
title: Topological photonic crystal applications

content:
QoT estimation has always been a crucial task for optical communication systems, by predicting the transmission OSNR, BER or any other indicator of quality, the desiners could know whether the link is trustworthy or not in advance, they can take actions such as change the route or give higher system margin.
QoT estimation has been studied for years, however we are still facing some challenges. Modern optical networks are dynamic and running in ultra high speed, the conventional QoT estimation methods remains to be statical and lack of efficiency. Our research in QoT estimation tries to propose novel methods using the state-of-the-art model for addressing such challenges.
summary: We developed algorithms for more rubust network transmission Quality estimation.
title: Quality of transmission estimation

summary: With up-to-date coverage and extensive treatment of various important topics related to machine learning for fiber-optic communication systems, this book is an invaluable reference for photonics researchers and engineers. It is also a very suitable text for graduate students interested in ML-based signal processing and networking.
title: Machine Learning for Future Fiber-Optic Communication Systems
